articles.title: Contact
articles.contents:
Contact details
üìç Australian National Phenome Centre.Murdoch University.
Level 3, Harry Perkins Institute.
5 Robin Warren Drive.
Murdoch, 6150, Western Australia.
üìß siobhon.egan@murdoch.edu.au
üìß siobhonegan@hotmail.com
Research links
  Home page 
  Research Gate 
  Github 
  ORCID 
  Google Scholar 
  Scopus 






Webpages
I (attempt) to keep my data analysis skills sharp during my research and maintain the following websites:
Personal page - RStudio, intro to sequence analysis & phylogenetics
Cryptick lab group page - bioinformatics with NGS data

Media links
It was a privilege to share my experiences to-date with some keen high school students at the first Pawsey careers night in 2018 ‚Äì a write-up on the event is available here.
On the back of my internship with Pawsey I wanted to put my newly discovered bioinformatic skills to good use and started my PhD at Murdoch University. Pawsey invited me back to show where the diverse world of super-computing can take you. For me, it involves everything from the field, to the lab, and then onto the big wide world of coding. The video by Pawsey can be found here.

 Training & Skills

Research interests: Microbes, Parasites, Genomics, Bioinformatics, Phylogenetics. Ticks (Ixodida), Infectious disease, Zoonoses, One Health, High-throughput sequencing, Molecular Biology, Epidemiology, Vector-borne disease, Haemoprotozoa
 Education
Doctor of Philosophy Murdoch University | 2018‚Äì2021 (tentative submission in June)
Ecology of ticks and tick-borne diseases in Australia: A One Health approach.
Supervisors: Dr.¬†Charlotte Oskam, Prof.¬†Peter Irwin, Prof.¬†Una Ryan, and Prof.¬†Peter Banks.
Use of molecular tools to investigate the epidemiology of tick (and other vector) associated microbes (bacteria and protozoa) present in Australian wildlife.
Bachelor of Science Honours Murdoch University | 2017
Major in molecular biology First class
Profiling the microbiome of ticks parasitising Australian bandicoots copy available here
Supervisors: Dr.¬†Charlotte Oskam and Prof.¬†Peter Irwin
Application of next generation sequencing to characterise the bacterial composition of tick (Acari: Ixodida) and tissues samples
Bachelor of Science Murdoch University | 2014‚Äì2016
Double major in Animal Health and Conservation & Wildlife Biology
Distinction average
Independent study contract in final semester ‚Äì Small mammal camera trapping in Dryandra woodlands. Supervised by A/Prof Peter Spencer (Murdoch University) and Mark Cowan (Department of Parks and Wildlife WA).

Dietary analysis of feral pigs using Next Generation Sequencing

Supercomputing internship program sponsored by Pawsey and CSIRO in conjunction with Murdoch University (PI Dr.¬†Charlotte Oskam)
A video of my experiences as an intern available here

Research Training Program (RTP) Scholarship for tuition fees and stipend, awarded 2018.
Best poster design, Combined Biological Sciences Meeting, awarded August 2017.
Myrtle AB Lamb Honours Scholarship, awarded March 2017.

articles.title: Siobhon Egan
articles.contents:
Siobhon Egan
          
          
          Home
          CV
          Publications
          Tick ID
          Contact
          ‚ò∞
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Siobhon Egan
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                        GitHub

                        LinkedIn
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Twitter
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            
            Welcome!
            I am a research fellow at Murdoch University based at the Centre for Computational and Systems Medicine and the Australian National Phenome Centre. I begun working under the direction of Prof.¬†Elaine Holmes, Centre Director Computational and Systems Medicine, in March 2021. Prof.¬†Holmes was awarded an Australian Laureate Fellowship (FL200100220) titled Understanding host-microbiome signalling axes in ageing. The project aims to deepen the understanding of host-microbiome signalling in ageing by: (i) bringing together next generation sequencing technologies to characterise age-associated change in gut bacterial composition, (ii) metabolic profiling to identify changes in functionality of the ageing microbiome, and (iii) a combination of in vitro and in vivo screening approaches to establish molecular mechanisms. The new knowledge will facilitate development of improved models of health care.
            I was fortunate to secure a post-doctoral research position during my PhD candidature, and as such I am currently in the final stages of my PhD thesis.
            My project was part of an ARC linkage grant (LP160100200) titled Tiresome ticks: Ecology and transmission of tick-borne disease in Australia. This project was led by the Vector and Waterborne Pathogens Research Group at Murdoch University and aimed to identify and characterise the microbial biodiversity in ticks and wildlife reservoir hosts, providing important insights into potential causative agent(s) of zoonotic tick-borne pathogens.
            I completed a Bachelor of Science in Animal Health and Wildlife & Conservation Biology with first class honours in Molecular Biology.
            During my undergraduate studies (2014‚Äì2016), I developed a strong passion for wildlife health which evolved into my fascination with the interconnection of the health of the environment, animals and people. I spent time volunteering on a number of projects, and was heavily involved as a volunteer field and lab assistant into the woylie decline as part of Dr.¬†Amy Northover‚Äôs PhD. My interests expand to other areas of wildlife conservation, including the completion of an independent project on camera trapping of small mammals in Dryandra woodlands under the supervision of A/Prof Peter Spencer (Murdoch University) and Mark Cowan (Parks and Wildlife, Western Australia).
            My honours in Molecular Biology (2017) was titled ‚ÄòProfiling the bacterial microbiome of ticks that parasitise bandicoots in Australia‚Äô, under the supervision of Dr.¬†Charlotte Oksam and Prof.¬†Peter Irwin, and is available for download here. During my project I identified a number of recently described and novel candidate tick-borne pathogens in ticks parasitsing bandicoots (Order: Peramelemorphia).
            With no time to rest, I undertook a paid summer internship with Pawsey Supercomputing Centre in November 2017, diving into all things coding and bioinformatics.
            
            
            
            I started my PhD in 2018, as a continuation of the number of questions that arose from my honours project. Under the supervision of Dr.¬†Charlotte Oksam, Prof.¬†Peter Irwin, Prof.¬†Una Ryan and Prof.¬†Peter Banks (University of Sydney). My project is titled Ecology of ticks and microbes in Australia. I hope to uncover patterns in the life cycle of ticks and their related microbes in Australian wildlife and investigate the overlap with cases of human tick-borne illnesses.
            
            
          
        
      
    

    
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Siobhon Egan

              Welcome!
              I am a research fellow at Murdoch University based at the Centre for Computational and Systems Medicine and the Australian National Phenome Centre. I begun working under the direction of Prof.¬†Elaine Holmes, Centre Director Computational and Systems Medicine, in March 2021. Prof.¬†Holmes was awarded an Australian Laureate Fellowship (FL200100220) titled Understanding host-microbiome signalling axes in ageing. The project aims to deepen the understanding of host-microbiome signalling in ageing by: (i) bringing together next generation sequencing technologies to characterise age-associated change in gut bacterial composition, (ii) metabolic profiling to identify changes in functionality of the ageing microbiome, and (iii) a combination of in vitro and in vivo screening approaches to establish molecular mechanisms. The new knowledge will facilitate development of improved models of health care.
              I was fortunate to secure a post-doctoral research position during my PhD candidature, and as such I am currently in the final stages of my PhD thesis.
              My project was part of an ARC linkage grant (LP160100200) titled Tiresome ticks: Ecology and transmission of tick-borne disease in Australia. This project was led by the Vector and Waterborne Pathogens Research Group at Murdoch University and aimed to identify and characterise the microbial biodiversity in ticks and wildlife reservoir hosts, providing important insights into potential causative agent(s) of zoonotic tick-borne pathogens.
              I completed a Bachelor of Science in Animal Health and Wildlife & Conservation Biology with first class honours in Molecular Biology.
              During my undergraduate studies (2014‚Äì2016), I developed a strong passion for wildlife health which evolved into my fascination with the interconnection of the health of the environment, animals and people. I spent time volunteering on a number of projects, and was heavily involved as a volunteer field and lab assistant into the woylie decline as part of Dr.¬†Amy Northover‚Äôs PhD. My interests expand to other areas of wildlife conservation, including the completion of an independent project on camera trapping of small mammals in Dryandra woodlands under the supervision of A/Prof Peter Spencer (Murdoch University) and Mark Cowan (Parks and Wildlife, Western Australia).
              My honours in Molecular Biology (2017) was titled ‚ÄòProfiling the bacterial microbiome of ticks that parasitise bandicoots in Australia‚Äô, under the supervision of Dr.¬†Charlotte Oksam and Prof.¬†Peter Irwin, and is available for download here. During my project I identified a number of recently described and novel candidate tick-borne pathogens in ticks parasitsing bandicoots (Order: Peramelemorphia).
              With no time to rest, I undertook a paid summer internship with Pawsey Supercomputing Centre in November 2017, diving into all things coding and bioinformatics.
              
              
              
              I started my PhD in 2018, as a continuation of the number of questions that arose from my honours project. Under the supervision of Dr.¬†Charlotte Oksam, Prof.¬†Peter Irwin, Prof.¬†Una Ryan and Prof.¬†Peter Banks (University of Sydney). My project is titled Ecology of ticks and microbes in Australia. I hope to uncover patterns in the life cycle of ticks and their related microbes in Australian wildlife and investigate the overlap with cases of human tick-borne illnesses.

articles.title: Tick identification
articles.contents:
Guide to identification of Australian ticks (Ixodida) including pictorial guide to genera present in Australia.
Please cite as:
Egan S. (2019). Australian Tick (Ixodida) Identification Guide. https://doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.2.20101.99040
A main focus of my current research is identification of Australian ticks. As such I have developed the following resource that I have made freely available to help with tick identification.
You can also find a copy available on my research gate profile Australian Tick (Ixodida) Identification Guide.

Please don‚Äôt hesitate to contact me directly for advice or assistance with morphological identification of Australian ticks (contact page).
